title: Type A Machines Series 1 and U-T-O-M new style X stage with better linear bearing support.

description.text:
This is a mod to the previously released Type Machines Series one open source files. Pictures show the production bots now inlcude a similiar change but the released files by them have not been updated.  
This mod is basically an adaptation of the design from pictures to incorportate the changes.  
The "why" behind it is that when you tension the X belt, it tends to flex the lower mounting plate making both the idler and the motor not 90 degrees to the axis and belt travel, thus the belt tends to walk to one side and rub on the pulleys. In addition, the extra tabs prevent the original Y bearing holder "ears" from flexing and thus causing minor Y slop. Basically, this is a simple mod to connect via tabs, and "box in" the X stage ends more completely adding rigidity and precision to the machine. Again, Type A machines made these mods on production units, but this is an add on for the open source.

description.text:
This has been a pet project of mine for a few weeks now; I originally started it to learn how to do surface modeling in Solidworks and well, it kinda spiraled out of control very soon after that. However, since I've other projects on table I haven't been able to work on this in awhile and I thought I'd share how far I got in case someone else wants to use these files as a base for something else, or remix or even finish the RC side in this. :) Currently the chassis is pretty much done; it features opening doors and hatches, as well as working side door slider mechanism. A lot of inspiration for the steering and suspension came from OpenRC projects;
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:42198
so a lot of thanks for these folks! Things that needs to be designed still; Shocks/springs, rear suspension, powertrain and motor/servo/battery mounts. It's meant to be RWD and clumsy as the real one ;) tires can be printed out from flexible materials such as NinjaFlex and otherwise hardware used is pretty common 10x4x3 bearings, some 3mm and 1mm studs/rods and M3 screws. Included are Solidworks .STLPRT files for easier derivates and modifications. AS FOR NOW, THIS IS MODEL IS NOT READY FOR RC BUT CAN BE PRINTED AS A DECORATION MODEL. RUN THE FILES THROUGH NETFABB FIRST IF YOU INTEND TO PRINT IT.

description.text: I love my Hue light bulbs... I don't love it when they get turned off at the switch and I can't remotely control them! I found there is plenty of ways to disable US style light switches but nothing for us over here across the pond... I designed this part for a standard single gang UK light switch and it should work for most single and twin switches. I put some holes in the front so that you can use any sort of thin stick to operate the switches should you absolutely need to (I sized the holes for the little plastic sticks used to make cotton buds with the fluffy bit cut off.)

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

P3Steel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes: I printed this two ways, both worked so its really down to your printer and preferences.
  • Print it laying down flat with support material under the raised part.
  • Print it vertically, you will probably need to use a brim as the footprint on the bed will be pretty small, I had a few come loose before I added the brim.
    • I printed it in silver PLA, but I'm sure almost any other type of filament you like would work!

Be Safe! Before doing this, turn off the power to your lights at the consumer unit. If you aren't sure how to do this then get some help.... this job isn't for you! Remove Screws Take the two screws out that hold the switch face to the back box and thread them through the printed part. Attach to Wall Re attach screws to the front of the switch, through the printed part and make sure they're not over tightened. Power It Up Turn the power back on at the consumer unit and use anything thin enough to poke through the cover and set the switches to be on.

title: Salt Box Table Top Trash Can

description.text:
This thing will convert an empty Morton or similar salt box into a handy table top trash can. The base is to counter act the top heaviness of the prototype.
IGES or STEP files can be supplied on request. Sorry people, I missed a file. I originally tried an all-in-one print that failed on my printer. That file was included. I split the top ring and lid to seperate files and the top ring in now included

The lid is designed to use a length of 1.75mm filament as a hinge pin, with a drop of glue to keep it in place.
Use support on the print of the lid as the hinge barrel protrudes below the lid flap. If you want to try an all-in-one print, go for your highest resolution. The clearance gaps did not all come thru for me. Thus the seperate lid flap and ring.

Have a table that's just not tall enough?  Want to add an extra shelf or storage space?  Well here's your solution--these nifty little legs will allow you to add a second top to your table.  The legs screw into the underside of a piece of wood, and snap into the caps on top of the table.  
This increases your table height by about four inches without permanently modifying your table.  Lets will hold up to normal table use, but use the original tabletop when lifting or pushing the table.  A cheap and easy solution to a real annoyance.
Use one leg and cap per corner, plus any additional legs for middle support.  Print at higher than normal infill (I used 50%) for strength.

title: Amadon's Cyclops and Chimera Direct Drive Version 3

description.text:
EDIT: 6/28/16
Added a V4 of the extruder body. The only difference is the holes for the PTFE tubing go all the way through so you can just make your own cutout for the drive gear, instead of worrying about making the tube the exact length.

EDIT 6/6/16 Added new version of the idlers These new idlers have support for the bearings on both sides so it can't bend over and lose clamping pressure on the filament.
There's a 0.4mm thick support material built in that you must cut out. No support needed from your slicer. Use a washer on BOTH sides of the roller bearing. Low profile nut of course. The flat side of the idlers should face towards the motors. Slightly raised sides towards the center. Put the nut on the motor side.

description.header: I used to have a complete printer here, but the title made no sense so that is now published separately here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1259225/
description.text:
This is an updated and more reliable version of my thing seen here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:961555 The primary difference between this and V2 is that you don't cut the PTFE tubes off flush with the top of your cold end. They extend up into the extruder body just below where the gear feeds the filament through the hole. This provides less bind points since now your extruder top doesn't have to line perfectly up with the bottom of the body itself. The PTFE tubes in my print of this extruder are 47mm long, but when you first assemble this, cut the two PTFE tubes to about 50mm long and try to put the cold end on. If they are too long trim off about 1mm and try again. Repeat until your PTFE tubes are exactly the right length so they are snug but still let the holes on the back of your cold end match up with the printed extruder body. TIP: Don't make the PTFE TOO snug. If you do, the part that contacts at the bottom of the PTFE tube is resting on a U shaped reduction in diameter. This part gets hot. If your PTFE is too long it'll soften and try to squeeze down into that U shape and get smaller. This will cause the inside of the bottom of the PTFE to be smaller than your filament and it will bind. MAKE SURE THE PTFE IS EXACTLY THE RIGHT LENGTH. I had mine a little too long, by about a mm, and ended up having to heat my hot end hot enough to somewhat liquify the PTFE, and push my filament through by hand until I had extruded the PTFE that was touching my filament and causing it to bind. Big pain in the butt. So make sure your PTFE is not so long that you have to apply a lot of pressure to make the screw holes match up. Either that, or just put it all together with the heat brakes not inserted all the way and then move them up. Then level them. The difference between the two X carriages is minor. The Chimera one has easier access to the upper rear grub screws on in the Chimera cold end and also allows you to slide the lower bearings out of the way to get to the lower grub screws. Just slide the bearings all the way towards the center once you have both nozzles exactly the same height and have tightened the grub screws again. It should hold the bearings in place just fine. Mine does. Parts for extruder assembly:
2 10mm M5 screws: http://www.mcmaster.com/#93070a121/=wnovg7
2 low profile M5 nuts: http://www.mcmaster.com/#90695a037/=wnndyn
2 5x10x4 ball bearings: http://www.amazon.com/Bearing-5x10x4-Shielded-Miniature-Bearings/dp/B002BBGE56
2 Washers between the idler and the 5x10x4 bearings. http://www.mcmaster.com/#93475a230/=109ocpw
If you don't use these washers your bearings won't spin. You will have to drill the washers out to 5mm I.D.
2 M4 screws for the idlers: http://www.mcmaster.com/#93070a109/=wnnqj3
2 M4 nuts for the idlers: http://www.mcmaster.com/#90725a010/=wnosvm
2 MK8 drive gears which can be found all over the place online.
Cut some M3 threaded rod and make 3 lengths that are 120mm long. These will mount the motors to the whole thing.
2 springs: http://www.mcmaster.com/#94125k658/=yy1s7h
You will have to trim the springs shorter and use trial and error to get the length just right for tension.
You will probably need a couple washers on the M4 screws to keep the springs from slipping past the screw heads. You can download my configuration.h here: http://pastebin.com/4izq94YL
It's configured to use a Chimera, so if you have a Cyclops just change (#define EXTRUDERS) to 1.
I gave my printer the custom name "augmentation" so it'd say "augmentation ready" when it was ready to print. You can change this to whatever you like.
I believe I listed all the screws and such but if I missed anything let me know! Thanks and enjoy! EDIT: Added access holes for the mounting screws for the Chimera/Cyclops in the X carriage. This way if they come loose you don't have to disassemble anything to tighten them again.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T9Ya5-5jXGc

comments.text: Awesome job! Question about your experience with the Chimera, I designed a tilt mechanism to rotate the chimera as the unused nozzle sometimes touches or drags the the print, with perfectly level bed and nozzles. Do you have same experience with this? How do you fight ooze in this setup, do you retract unused nozzle? Currently I have a Bowden setup and am interested in using your setup to print flexible and pva easier.
comments.author: edkroket

comments.text:
You shouldn't get any dragging if everything is perfectly level, except for if your print curls up. Always print with both heaters on even if you're only using one and it'll help with that. But ive found its easier to level them by loosening the screws that attach the whole thing and rocking it slightly and re tightening rather than move the heat brakes up and down. Those are a huge pain in the ass. Of course you have to get them reasonably close to the same height first.
Use a sheet of paper or feeler gauges and put it between the nozzles (well cleaned off) and the bed and adjust until both drag on the paper equally.
comments.author: edkroket

comments.text:
Hi,
Thanks for your quick response, good one,I haven't tried heating both heaters equally. I had the unused nozzle could which would 'slightly touch'. I'll try your suggestion.
The retract for unused I have been struggling with. I used 6 before, but it caused the nozzle to jam, the filament melted in the hot end is slightly thicker than the ptfe tube. By retracting so much, the cooled down filament got stuck in the tube causing a jam. But this was with 40 mm/sec. maybe the 100mm will stretch the filament causing it to be thin and not jam.I'll give it a shot. Do you also reduce idle nozzle temperature during print to reduce ooze?
I had some issues with what I thought was heat creep. The cooling fan of the cold end of the Chimera does not cool that well. Probably using bad quality filament, which is my bad, but I did get jams every time after a few layers of printing PLA. I think it is due to friction in the system caused by the slightly increased temperature of the cold end. Of course I can use a wades or geared extruder, but that also creates more pressure differences in the Bowden due to speed changes. I use a filament filter with some oil to solve friction.
comments.author: Amadon

comments.text:
Yep! That's why I said 20mm. PLA (and ABS to a lesser extent) expands before it melts and if you don't retract it far enough it stays warm. You need to get it cool while it's retracted or it'll be too wide to fit back down the heat brake when it's time to print again.
You make a good point. It might be stretching it. I never thought of that.
Iv'e never used a lower idle temp. I use Repetier-Host and I'm not even sure that's an option. But by keeping both at full temp, if your print curls it'll have a better chance of melting through instead of banging into it and jumping steps.
I agree the fan on the Chimera sucks. What I did to help with this is have both the heat brakes sticking out a bit further than they need to, effectively making the distance between the hot and cold end longer. I also have a computer fan hairsprayed down on the end of my print bed with a speed controller on it. I let it blow on the entire hot end. But you can't turn it so high you trigger thermal runaway protection, so it takes practice.
Here's the fan controller I use. http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=9SIA9F93JU8914

comments.text:
Bent m3 rod isn't a big deal. It'll straighten out inside the assembly. Mine was bent too. I just hand straightened it and off I went.
Now remember the three rods that hold the motors to the body go all the way through both motors, so you have to take three of the screws that hold the motors together out. I did not try to build it with the threading still inside the motors, I just drilled mine out. But it's worth a shot if you don't feel comfortable drilling out the threads inside your motors. Without drilling out the threads it might be hard to get the motors to sit tightly agains the printed body. After it's all put together they will again be supported by all 4 holes. Oh, you might wanna put tiny washers on the ends of the m3 rod so you have a way to keep the nut from hiding inside the little divet the screw head used to sit in.

I picked up the EZ robot kit because I wanted to make a 3D printed robot and the setup has some nice features and did not look like it had too much of a learning curve to get started. I am still playing with the software but I do have it up and running. This thing will probably be a work in progress forever but I wanted to share the project anyway. I am also going to try and get a video up sometime. A short video of the Traxbot navigating by itself located here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9vWaPmw7uMo Thanks to Nevil_Clavin for his gear bearing derivative:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:71033
And Emmett for his original:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53451
As these things started the whole creavite process on this robot project.

I added the Solidworks files, they are messy but if you want to make changes this may make it easier for you. Update***
I have added a ver2 of the servo holder for the drive servos. It moves the servos close together to bring the tracks up on the base's posts better. It also has thicker arms and is a little taller, there was not much room to adjust the tracks before. I have tested it nd it works and also brings the idlers all the way onto the base. Note***
If you build this with the kit and it comes with the bulky screw on battery disconnect it will not fit in this orientation. I cut the end off an old battery charger and soldered it to an on/off switch I mounted under the car. It will work without the switch of course but I forgot the kit comes with a bulkier plug. You can try turning the board box around so the plug is in the front if you want. First thing I did was buy the EZ-robot Kit at http://www.ez-robot.com/ This kit has all the electronics I used for this project.
Print off some pieces...
106 tread pieces
2 drive gears
3 servo holders
4 of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:71033
and 1 of all the other pieces. The track is assembled by putting 53 pieces together in a loop using 17Ga wire nails. I used one inch nails and had to alternate the side I started in because some were shorter than others and would cause weird stretching if I did them all from one side. The holes are purposely tight so that the smaller side will hold the nail in place and the outside does the pivoting. The servo holder for the drive servos are slotted so they can be pushed up to tighten the track. This can be done with the drive gears on or off, there are slots that will allow a precision screwdriver through to tighten screws. The pieces that mount to a servo, (camera, ultrasonic sensor, drive gears) are designed to have a servo horn attached and then mounted with screws to the appropriate piece. Some servo horns I had to drill out the hole to accommodate the screw. For the Ultrasonic sensor there is a 4 pin connector that you need to attach wires to. Best thing I found was to dig into an old tower and cut off a usb header, then solder that to the wires for connecting to the EZ board. That way there isn't a solder joint right where the ultrasonic moves back and forth. The kit comes with a 6 AA battery pack that I have mounted underneath the base, and there are pre-made holes for everything that I have attached here. I am not sure what everyone will need/want to know so any questions feel free to ask, I will try to update more when I get more time/ambition.

comments.text:
I printed the Traxbot entirely on my replicator 2. I do use RepG and sailfish normally, but I did slice a few of these with makerware. I did not need any rafts or supports for these pieces. the base would have been almost impossible for me to print before I got my glass beds and began using aquanet hairspray to coat the bed with. Information on this if you want/need it can be found on the makerbot operator google group. If you search "cold glass" you should find several threads on printing to cold glass. My base came out flat and smooth with zero warping. Only other upgrade you need is that spring loaded extruder-any one of them is better than the plunger.
I think I printed the base with 20 percent infill for strength on the arms. Other than that I used pretty standard settings.
comments.author: hexalot

comments.text: I printed the whole model on a replicator 2. The base is a big flat area and Before I switched to a glass bed and began coating it in aquanet hairspray this would have been almost impossible to print. With this upgrade the bottom is as flat as the glass it was made on. I did not need to use rafts or support on any on the pieces. A few of them need to be oriented, like the camera pieces. Most pieces to not require a lot of special settings. I think I used a higher infill on the base for strength on the Idlers. If you want information on printing directly on cold glass with hairspray I suggest going to the Makerbot Operators google group and searching for "cold glass" there are several threads that have information on the subject- https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/makerbothttps://groups.google.com/foru...
comments.author: hexalot

comments.text: Thanks to you both for the input. I do have a glass bed and have been using hairspray for some time, I have also printed many mods to work out the typical bugs with this thing(this community is spectacular). In the case of the main "base", I actually had the model upside down xD RepG's default yellow color scheme doesn't show detail to well, i didnt notice that one side was more flat than the other. It printed without error once it was rotated. The bridging on the servo box still worries me, but ill cross it when I come to it :p Thanks again for the reply and upload :)

I recently shared a design that lets you mount your phone to a gorillapod.  I was (and am) really proud of the design, but it's a pretty niche thing.
This design is more universal. It makes use of a standard 1/4-20 nut and lets your phone be mounted to any tripod (including the gorillapod)
The model is fully parametric as before, so you can specify the dimensions of your phone, as well as that of the nut. as with the previous design, if you get dimensions that work with your phone, please comment.  I'll upload an STL so that subsequent users won't need to play around with openSCAD.

title: Filament Monitor for Prusa Direct Drive Extruder

description.text:
Update: I have finally completed this make but ended up using this sensor instead: http://www.amazon.com/Effect-Magnetic-Sensor-Module-Arduino/dp/B013JM7ALC/ref=sr_1_6?ie=UTF8&qid=1450704779&sr=8-6&keywords=arduino+hall+sensor&refinements=p_85%3A2470955011 This sensor board also fits well in the redesigned idler and has the benefit of an LED to indicate it is activated. This makes it easier for positioning the magnet on the correct orientation. You can see the video of the out-out-of filament condition. The printer continues for a few seconds after it stops extruding and then pauses the print and turns off the nozzle heat. Video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y0m4yF3LVSc ========================= I have redesigned the extruder idler from mrice's Wilson extruder design to implement the filament monitor created by gigl. (see remixed from for details) 1) Added grove in one of the bearing holder sides to accommodate the magnet
2) Added a square hole inside the bearing holder to mount the hall effect chip
3) Added a wiring channel
4) Added hole in between the 2 spring loaded screw holes to add a screw to calibrate the minimum distance between the bearing and the hobbed bolt. This is to ensure the bearing will not rotate for a filament run-out condition.

description.text:
Mounting block for a switched power inlet*. The tabs on either side of the inlet need to be pressed out to the side before inserting power cord. You may need to mirror the part or flip the switch around to orient the switch the way you want (the switch portion can be removed and rotated). You may want to use insulated 0.187" female spade connectors [22-16 gauge*] [14-16 gauge*] to wire the switch. The power inlets don't come with a fuse, you'll probably want a 250V 5mmx20mm fast blow fuse* if you're using it with a 3d printer. The current rating (in amps) will depend on the printer. Check out this post if you need help with wiring or fuse selection. Filaments: (full list can be found on thrinter.com)

Made in openscad this is a flip lock for an older hard bodied pop up camper. A friend had one that had several of these locking clips broken on. I took about an hour to make the OpenScad script and then fine tune and parametize it. If you need to make a different size then the STL provided, visit the customizer to make your version of the lock. This is designed to hold panels onto the side of a pop up camper in place once assembled. The lock swings down in front of the panel to keep it from coming out. A screw goes through the backside of the mounting panel to attach to rounded mount. These can be used in any location where a swing lock would come in handy.

The text was printed at the .5 setting in the list and is almost too small to be legible with a .4 tip as it tends to fill in the fine detail gaps in the lettering. Printed out with 1 extra shell and 100% fill since it is a structural part.  Print out and hammer onto the chair leg.  Fixed!

description.text: This is a printable add-on for your build platform.  You can pair it with some springs to easily adjust and level your build platform without any tools!

• Print out some thumbnuts
  • Press-fit M3 nuts into printed thingies.
  • Remove your build platform. Of the two M3 nuts per M3 machine screw used to adjust the distance between your x-stage and build platform, remove the one used for adjustment. Find six springs of equal length and feed them over the M3 screws.
  • Put the build platform back, and use the thumbnuts to adjust and level your platform without the need for tools.
    • Notes on the springs:
    I used the listed McMaster-Carr springs because I have a heavy copper plate as my build surface, and I needed a sufficiently strong spring. However, for your run-of-the-mill T-O-M, this will be overkill. I'm sure somewhere in the wide world there is an easy source for the perfect spring for this application, but I haven't looked too hard. I'm thinking the free pens they have at the bank are a good place to start. If anyone finds a place to salvage springs from, please share!

comments.text: Please let me know how this works for you over time.  I tried this about 6 months ago, and crashed spectacularly.  I used ball point pen springs, but I found that as the HBP heated (and each nut at a different rate) the springs became mushy and inconsistent.  The platform was rising and falling, and resulted in extruder crashes into the model, ruining it.

author: Andrea-123

title: Bulldog XL++ (a Bulldog XL despaghettification accessory)

description.text:
Filament was sometimes spaghettified from my Bulldog XL. Closer analysis of the design showed that there is quite a large gap from the hobbed surface to the exit hole; this 3d printed accessory fills the gap and eliminates any deviance of the filament. As a side effect; it also makes it easier to feed in the filament. Instructions:
  • Print with high infill (95% perhaps).
  • Clean up print with sandpaper; it's quite a tight fit so any protrusions/blobs will make it impossible to fit.
  • Drill holes out to 3mm for 1.75mm filament. This design is untested with 3mm filament.
  • Fit into Bulldog XL assembly, ensuring that the bearing can rotate freely.
    If not, then it could be one of many things such as bad print scale, printer prone to unsized holes or needing to clean up the inside face with sandpaper and/or scalpel.

author: mcbutler

description.text:
A parametric measuring spoon with an angled grip.
The volume of the bowl can be specified in ml. Image shows a 2ml version (and some too cheap, green tee ;-). The provided 5ml example equals a teaspoon, but I highly recommend to create your own with the included OpenSCAD source file.

Fire up OpenSCAD and load the source file.
Only six parameters need to be considered: volume = 5.0; // volume of the spoon in ml thickness = 1.4; // thickness of wall in mm gripDia = 7.0; // diameter of the grip gripLen = 80.0; // length of the grip gripAngle = 30.0; // angle of the bowl-grip joint sink = 0.4; // cut off the bottom a bit Most of them should be self explanatory.
Pick a volume, a wall thickness and make the grip "look good" afterwards... The "sink" parameter cuts off a bit of the spoon's bottom and makes it flat. This results in a better adhesion to the printing bed. Small spoons (e.g. <5ml) may still require a raft. For goods that need to be measured by weight and not volume, it might be helpful to print a quick size test.
If you set the following variable to "1" MINITESTGRIP = 0; // print test grip? 0/1 (off/on) the grip will be cut off and the resulting rest can be printed much quicker.

This model is a deriviative of World Trade Center by BrentA on the Google Sketchup 3D Warehouse. http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=808bef05686def6fa3b08fd9ebe3d105 Having a model is definitely not the same as having the real WTC and its' people back again. On the 10th anniversary of September 11th, I wanted to print a copy of the World Trade Center. Finding nothing on Thingiverse, I used this excellent model from the Sketchup Warehouse. The original is an extremely complex model. I converted the groups into shapes, added a base, and scaled it way down to a printable size in Sketchup. In Replicator G, I scaled it some more, and generated the GCode for a Cupcake Makerbot with a heated build platform. The towers have double walls, so are not filled with honeycombs.

Print
See what the geography of the WTC site used to be. This might be improved by adding LEDs to the inside of the towers and a battery to the base. The design has an empty cavity below the towers, which makes it kind of fragile. This part of the stl file should be changed for durability.

With this parts you will be able to print and build your own customizable compound bow or cross-bow. Suggested ammunition are long straws, chopstick, real arrows or anything with similar size.

description.text:
Well, not sure what use this is, but my kids seemed to think it was necessary.  Doesn't really bounce that well of course but you can bounce coins off of it.  Perhaps would make a better drum.
I think I might need to seek help for a makerbot addiction soon...

I print this using raftless printing configured basically how they describe on the makerbot wiki (http://wiki.makerbot.com/thingomatic-doc:raftless). The modifications I made are: 1) I changed the Object First Layer Feed Rate Infill Multiplier (ratio) to be 0.5 2) I change the Object First Layer Feed Rate Permieter Multiplier (ratio) to 0.5 3) I changed the Object First Layer Flow Rate Multiplier (ratio) to 0.9 4) I disabled the Outline feature and generally delete the lines of gCode that do the warm up extrusion. These changes make the first layer go down slower and a little wider/thicker so that it adheres to the platform very well. I was noticing that the outline and warm-up extrusion generally left buggers or lines of plastic that then caused the early layers to peal off. The changes above fixed that.

remixed_from.author: villekl
remixed_from.title: Modular X-ends || Sturdy & Easy to Print

title: Heavily Modified (Modular) X ends w/ endstop holder.

description.text:
Updates are at bottom of text NOTE
When installing these ends pinch the M8 nuts with your fingers and try to get them as tight as possible using the threaded rod run it threw the nuts and attach to your couplings. I will post a better install instruction later, as they are a bit tricky to install. The pulley mount goes on last as well as the motor mount bracket etc. Original Post
See I have this problem, I have to alter and modify anything I can so here are the X-ends from villekl only modified a slight bit. There is now an enstop holder that mounts to the top of the x motor end, as well as a pass through on the x motor mount for those of us with long smooth rods, also there are nut traps for m3 nuts on the bottom of the XendBaseV2.stl I have not installed these as of yet, but plan to install them sometime this weekend. I will update the post and let you know how they work. Update #2
Installed and updated the design once again, the ID for the rods have been made 9mm to give a little leeway for some printers. My printer does not do bridges very well. If they are loose a wrap or two of blue tape works well. Bearing wells have a bearing lip to hold the bottom of the bearing in place, as well as a spot for a zip tie in the middle of the bearing tower. Extended "wings" have been added to the ends as well to provide even clamping around the bars, as well as some other smaller modifications. After installing I notice almost no z wobble if any at all. Update #1
I have installed the X_motor mount and have noticed a few issues, and have made changes to the X_motor mount top, bottom, and mount itself. The pass through holes for the rods were not big enough to properly hold the M8 rods. Bolt insets have been added for people who use 20mm m4 bolts like I do. Support has been added to the bearing wells as well as the bearing wells them selfs have been gutted a little to add just a bit of wiggle room. I almost needed a vice to put my bearings in. Once I install this set I will update and let everyone know how they work. Printed Parts
Both extended and regular versions will work. Regular motor mount and pulley mount will not mount properly to the extended versions. Regular ends "No wing"
1 x XendStopHolder V2.stl <-- not required
2 x Top_X_Motor_V3.stl
2 x Bottom_X_Motor_V5.stl
1 x X_Motor_Mount_V5.stl
1 x X_End_Idler_V3.stl Extended Ends
2 x Bottom_X_Motor_V6.stl
2 x Top_X_Motor_V4.stl
1 x X_Motor_Mount_V6.stl
1 x X_End_Idler_V4.stl

author: OCybress

title: Thinkfun Maker Studio - Make It Move Expansion Set

description.text:
"Make It Move" with the new Thinkfun Maker Studio Make It Move Expansion Set! This set features six new components to assist in building more complex and more movable creations. Gear Chain
Hook gears together and transfer rotational power from a distance! Two parts (Chain Link and Chain Pin), with multiple STL file configurations available. Hinge
Connect two rods together and make them move with this hinge component. Three parts (Hinge Conn 1, Hinge Conn 2, and Hinge Pin). Print them all at once using the combined "Hinge" STL file. Segmented Swivels
This component can be used to shape curving rods. There are three parts to this component. The Swivel Ball Rod is the starting piece. From there, you can connect Swivel Segments (as many as you'd like). Then, you cap it off with a Swivel Socket Rod piece. Multiple STL file configurations available. 6-Way Rod Connector
A simple but necessary piece for connecting rods in 6 directions. A single part print. Reciprocating Gear
Another simple but necessary piece. This (large) gear has an added rod attachment hole. Use it as a crank, or to transfer rotational movement to linear movement. A single part print. Extra Large Wheel
Need a bigger wheel? Yeah, I did too. That's why the incredible "Extra Large Wheel" has made its way into the expansion set! Never have you been more amazed at the size of a wheel! Look at it, and feel free to wonder at its abundant abundance. A single part print (if your 3D printer is big enough!!!).

Note: I have not test printed these items, because I do not have a 3D printer or reasonable access to one. I worked hard on this set in hopes to win one! I also worked hard on this set to ensure the parts fit right, and print easily. Thank you for your understanding.

comments.text: I used Blender. It has a physics engine, but it's very touchy. I do use the physics engine to test things. Basically, with complex object structures like the bike here, if it can hold together for a second or two, it should be good to go. Other tools I use are the built-in Blender mesh cleanup tools, the 3D printing Blender add-on, the export selected Blender add-on, and the free version of netfabb that I triple check my STLs with. Other than that, it's reviewing peoples test prints/benchmarks, thinking through how things need to be printed, clearances, etc. Thanks!
